Triggering Event: Dr. M was scrubbing in for surgery when he overheard the circulating nurse praise his colleague, Dr. J, for yesterday's procedure. "He's so talented," she gushed. M felt a pang of envy, gripping his scalpel tighter.
Generated Assessment: "Wow, I'm just... so... mediocre." Dr. M said this to himself as he began scrubbing in, though he hadn't consciously planned to express that sentiment. He realized it was an irrational thought, but his mind wouldn't let go of it. The comment from the circulating nurse about Dr. J had triggered something inside him, and now he couldn't shake off the feeling that he wasn't good enough.

Triggering Event: While restocking shelves at work, she found an old photograph tucked behind a book's cover, of her and her husband on their wedding day. The sight of his smile brought sudden, quiet tears streaming down her face.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but notice how much more attractive he looked than he did now, with those youthful eyes sparkling in contrast to the grey hair he'd accumulated since then. She felt no need to acknowledge the happiness that photo represented; it was just something from her past, like an old memory. She didn't bother trying to hold back her emotions as the tears fell, but instead thought about all the other things that could have triggered such feelings, none of which were pleasant. She pushed through the sadness, focusing on the task at hand, rather than dwelling on the positive memories associated with the picture.

Triggering Event: After a long day at the clinic, she returned home to find her husband sitting in his favorite armchair, newspaper spread out before him, untouched dinner cooling on the table beside him. His eyes barely flickered as she entered, absorbed in an article about a young surgeon's groundbreaking research. She felt a familiar resentment rise within her, bitter and heavy like the untasted food.
Generated Assessment: She often feels this way when he spends hours reading while I work tirelessly, taking care of our household and caring for others. It makes me wonder if he even notices my efforts, if he even cares. He doesn't seem to notice how hard I'm working, how much stress I carry. When I try to talk to him, he's too engrossed in his paper to listen, completely ignoring me. Sometimes it feels like he'd rather read than spend time with me. The thought that he might not appreciate everything I do for him fills me with anger and frustration. Why does he always have so much time to himself? Doesn't he know that I'm tired from all my responsibilities? Sometimes I feel like I'm just an afterthought to him, someone who exists solely to support his interests. Even though we agreed to share responsibilities, I never see him lifting a finger to help. He doesn't acknowledge my struggles or show appreciation for what I do. If anything, he seems more interested in his own pursuits than in spending quality time with us. It’s as if he believes his hobbies are more important than my needs. That must be why he can’t spare a moment for me, why he reads all evening instead of joining me. The truth is, I feel forgotten in his life, left behind in favor of his books. Triggering Event: A young, fit recruit effortlessly completes an obstacle course that had once left her breathless, while she struggles to navigate it, her reflection in the shiny surface mocking her slowing reflexes and growing fatigue.
Generated Assessment: "Wow, you're so strong! You must be able to lift heavy weights all the time."

Triggering Event: She was halfway through her shift at the hospital when she noticed it - a scathing comment about her carelessness, scrawled in red ink across her patient's chart. She knew that handwriting, could feel the anger bubbling up inside her like lava in a volcano. It was from him, her colleague of ten years, who'd always found fault in everything she did. This time, though, it was personal. The patient, an elderly woman with dementia, had wandered off during his watch, ending up in the morgue by mistake. He'd blamed her, as he always did, but this time he'd gone too far. She felt her cheeks flush, her grip tightening around the chart until her knuckles turned white. She knew she couldn't lose it here, not with patients and colleagues all around, but she also knew she wouldn't let this go unanswered. Not again.
Generated Assessment: She's just a careless nurse, and that's why she keeps messing up. She can't even keep track of her own work properly, so how is she supposed to care for these patients? And now she's going to have to deal with another complaint about her incompetence? Why bother fixing anything when she's already a failure? This isn't the first time he's called her out like this, and it won't be the last. She knows he thinks he's better than everyone else, especially women, and he loves to remind her of that. But she'll never back down. She can handle it. After all, she’s been doing this job for over 15 years and has seen countless examples of people like him. They're always quick to judge, quick to blame, and quick to leave. She’ll get through this, no matter what he says. She needs to keep her cool, focus on the task at hand, and make sure those patients are taken care of. Nothing else matters right now except for the well-being of her patients. She can’t let him get under her skin; it would only give him power. She needs to show him that she doesn’t react to his insults. But deep down, she feels frustrated, angry, and hurt. Triggering Event: He noticed the message while grading papers after school: "It's over." No name, no explanation, just three words that echoed in his head like a distant thunderstorm.
Generated Assessment: He felt like he was drowning in an ocean of regret as he read those two sentences. It wasn't until later when he saw the signature - the same student who had been struggling since the beginning of the semester - that the weight of it all finally hit him. Why did he think about her? She hadn't even tried. The thought made him want to scream into the void, but he held back, knowing that would only make things worse. She had given up before even starting, and now she was going to get an F for missing class. Meanwhile, he was still working hard, pouring every ounce of energy into this project. But was it enough? He remembered how frustrated he'd gotten when his grades weren't improving despite his efforts, how desperate he'd become to see some sign of progress. And then there were the days spent crying over failed assignments, wondering if he was cut out for this course. Every time he looked at his grades, he felt like he was staring into the abyss - a reminder that he might never be good enough. But what really hurt was seeing her posts on social media. She didn't care enough to keep up with her schoolwork, let alone try for a higher grade. Yet, here she was, bragging about something entirely unrelated to academics. What was more frustrating was that she seemed happy, content with herself, like nothing could bring her down. It was infuriating. Triggering Event: "Upon arriving home, he found the once familiar scent of freshly brewed coffee replaced by silence and dust. The empty house echoed with memories of shared laughter and conversations, now reduced to hollow whispers in his mind."
Generated Assessment: "Whoa! What just happened? I guess it's been too long since we last hung out... Did he move away? Is everything okay? I'm starting to feel really weird about this. He never said anything, so what if he didn't want me to come over?"

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her lab, she hears a faint buzzing, growing louder, mimicking the relentless hum of grief she thought she'd silenced. Her breath catches as she realizes it's the alarm on his watch, still set to wake him for mornings they'll never have again. Panic surges, drowning out the sterile hum of her work.

The thoughts are like a virus spreading through my mind, infecting every cell with dread. I try to shake them off, but they cling to me like a shroud, suffocating me. My hands begin to shake, and my vision blurs. I feel like I'm drowning in this sea of fear, unable to find a lifeline to cling to. The noise from the lab is muffled, drowned out by the cacophony of what-ifs that scream in my ears. Every second feels like an eternity, each tick of time stretching into an endless expanse of hopelessness. I know I need to move, but my legs feel heavy, weighed down by the crushing weight of all these unspoken fears. I force myself to stand, but the world around me is distorted, as if reality itself is bending to accommodate the tidal wave of my anxiety. Each step feels like a betrayal, a betrayal against myself for being so weak. The noise grows louder, more insistent, a constant reminder of everything I’ve lost – and everything I could lose. I can’t breathe, can’t think, can’t escape the prison of my own mind. Every moment stretches out before me, a blank canvas waiting to be filled with the brushstrokes of despair. Triggering Event: He noticed the unopened birthday card still tucked in his desk drawer, meant for his nephew who lived across the country. It was now two months late.
Generated Assessment: This is so weird. Why would he put it there? Is this some kind of prank? Did he think I'd forget? How did he even remember? What's going on here? This is so strange.

Triggering Event: A woman in her 40s, a seasoned journalist, receives an email from her former colleague who had been promoted over her. The subject line reads: "Congrats on your recent piece - great job!" She opens it to find a subtle dig disguised as praise, insinuating that her article was merely "human interest" while his were "hard-hitting."
Generated Assessment: "I just can’t help but feel that she’s always trying to undermine me. I mean, look at how this latest email is framed – it's just another example of her being condescending. If I let one instance of this kind of behavior slide, why would I continue to tolerate it? It’s clear that she thinks she’s better than everyone else because she got that promotion. Her constant belittling comments are just proof that she doesn't respect anyone outside her inner circle." # Output End ### Output End Note: This example does not contain the distorted thought pattern, which could be "she has never respected me", instead it says "if I let one instance happen, why would I continue to tolerate it". But if we break down this sentence, we see that the actual distorted thought behind it is actually "she has always disrespected me". This is an example of Overgeneralization. We have taken a single negative experience (the email) and generalized it into our general belief about her character ("she has always disrespected me"). It makes sense to us that she will continue to disrespect us based on past instances, even though there may be many other times when she has treated us with kindness. By doing so, we overlook all the positive interactions between us and focus solely on these few incidents, leading to an inaccurate picture of her true nature. This type of thinking prevents us from seeing the bigger picture and understanding that people can behave differently depending on the situation.
